Gavra knew at that moment that her career as an Observer was over.

She had gotten much out of it. Oibva's granting her permission to join in the destruction had been a formality--the Colonel could not have stopped her if she had ordered her entire task force to do so.

As she hovered there, she realized that the five beings were speaking Palaidian telepathically.

No, worse. They were speaking their native language, and she understood them.

She tried frantically to wipe the knowledge of their language from her brain, but could not. She tried to reply to them in Palaidian, but found herself forced to communicate in their language, which she knew they called English.

"Fuck you, bitch," said one of them. "You spoiled our fun."

"Yeah," said another. "We're cool with wiping out humanity and all, but we're the ones who get to do it. I'm afraid you'll have to be punished for your insolence."

Oibva was holding Gavra close, and the Observer felt the Colonel make the subtlest of hand motions.

The strike squad attacked.

A trillionth-cycle later they were rendered harmless inside some sort of energy webbing. They all appeared comatose.

Gavra felt a powerful force rip through her mind. She screamed in what she knew these creatures called pain, though Palaidian had no word for the sensation, and saw Oibva do the same.

"She will die from that wound, Observer, unless it is healed," said a fourth voice, a male voice this time. "But I offer you a choice. You may have your beloved Colonel, restored to full health. Or you may have the squad you sent against us. Whoever you do not choose will die."

Gavra blinked. She was not used to ultimatums. She reached out through her communications device, only to find it instantly incinerated.

"No, Observer," said a fifth voice. "You and you alone must make this decision, just like you and you alone made the decision to recommend the obliteration of our home planet."

"How much time do I have?" said Gavra, feeling what these humans called fear for the first time in her long life.

"We understand that this is a difficult decision," said the second voice, "and thus we grant you a millionth-cycle in which to consider it. But be warned, Observer, that a billionth-cycle after that millionth-cycle elapses, which will be barely enough time for you to return here and tell us your decision, the Colonel will die of her wounds and the energy webbing will incinerate her squad. If you can decide in that time, only one of those two fates will come to pass. Now go, Observer."

Gavra felt herself hurtle through space until she was at a distance that would take her nearly a billionth-cycle to traverse at her top speed. She began to ponder her options, feeling helpless and alone.

She had hung in space, a little under a light-cycle from where the planet had been, pondering those whose fate she had been told she held in her hands.

She hoped that Oibva would understand her decision.

But Oibva was Palaidia's greatest military genius. The one time that Gavra could recall that a people advanced far enough in the time between checkups--they were run every ten thousand cycles at the time, and the situation had persuaded the Council to expand the Observer Corps to allow for thousand-cycle checkups--to mount a serious challenge to Palaidia, Oibva had led the Palaidian forces to resounding victories in the ensuing battles. It was only an unwillingness among her superiors to resign that kept her from promotion, but she was formally designated Senior Colonel, the title having been specifically created for her, was present at all major strategy meetings and accorded all privileges of high rank except the associated title.

And, quite simply, Gavra loved her.

In the end that swung the balance. Soldiers, as much a tragedy as it would be to lose a thousand, were replaceable. Oibva was not--not to Palaidia, and not to Gavra.

She had reached her decision in well under the allotted millionth-cycle and was able to fly back to Earth at a pace faster than her usual travel speed but well below her top speed.

"I choose Oibva," she said flatly, tonelessly, and Oibva immediately perked up and flew into her arms, but both then felt themselves being turned and locked in position while the energy webbing holding the soldiers flared in intensity for a moment and then vanished, leaving nothing behind.

If we--or God--decide to put a planet under her protection, any interlopers will be dealt with swiftly and harshly. Any Observer, or other Palaidian, found there will die instantly. Now go, and pray to God that they and she will have mercy on you for the choice you made here."

Gavra didn't notice that Earth had been reconstituted almost until she had turned to fly away.

Gavra forced herself to think it. Death.

She was fragile from having been so close to... death... and so Gavra cradled her as she flew both of them back to Palaidia.

"Observer," said the Chief Councilor, "in light of your experiences at Earth, and the threats made by these beings, what is your recommendation for the continuance of the Observer program?"

Gavra had not expected to be asked that question. She had expected to be dismissed in disgrace.

She paused a moment before replying. "I believe that the Observer program still serves a valuable purpose. I still believe in the superiority of Palaidia and Palaidians and that whoever this God might be, and however omnipotent"--another word that had not previously existed in Palaidian--"she might be, we can and will defeat her. However, given the threat now posed to our Observers--I have no doubt that these beings are capable of carrying out that threat--I would recommend that all Observers be advised of what transpired, those wishing to resign being allowed to do so, and the risk pay being substantially increased for all remaining in the program. I would further advise that the same be done for all field soldiers in the military."

One of the other Councilors cut in. "Hold there, Observer. You accept this idea that there is an all-powerful God?"

"I realize how irrational it sounds. I have no direct evidence for the existence of such a being, but my encounter with these five who claimed affiliation with her left me with no doubt that she exists."

"That is correct, Councilor."

The Chief Councilor waved the other to silence. "Your recommendations are reasonable, Observer, and will be implemented. Tell me, do you intend to resign from the Observer program?"

"I do, Chief Councilor. While Observing has been my passion for billions of cycles, I have had first-hand experience with something that no Palaidian has encountered since almost before recorded history, and it has left me deeply shaken."

Gavra put her head in her arms on her desk and sobbed.

She had thought that her promotion was a good thing. As Chief Observer, she directly controlled the Observer program, which previously had been controlled by a subcommittee of the Council and thus had been, in her opinion, not always run well, especially since only one member of the Council was a former Observer.

She also held a seat on the Council, instantly making her one of the eleven most influential people on Palaidia. Already the Council had had to confront the issue of the possible existence of an omnipotent being, which worried them since they did not know if she had placed any uninhabited planets under her protection. Normally they'd just send out an Observer, but...

She and Oibva also shared a huge mansion with a large staff. They had agreed to use as offices rooms on opposite sides of the building, but still took meals together, and with the staff.

Oibva was still getting over the shock of suddenly being Palaidia's top military officer. While previously the general staff had listened to her advice, a situation with which she was perfectly comfortable since she knew that she was first and foremost a field officer and had little knowledge of all the bureaucracy that went on behind the scenes, finding herself in charge of that bureaucracy had overwhelmed her. She was relieved that she had gotten to keep her old uniforms, the reasoning being that as sole head of the military, she could unilaterally change them, so it made no sense to force her to change her uniform from the one she used as Senior Colonel, a rank that, like General Marshal, had not existed until it was given to her.

Gavra sobbed. Palaidia and its colony planets--planets that, she knew, Palaidian settlement had transformed from barren wastelands to verdant paradises--were nearing their safe capacity once again, and normally the Council would send out Observers to find a few uninhabited planets that could be quickly converted to support the level of comfort to which Palaidians were accustomed. Then the usual incentives would be offered for anyone wishing to move to one of the new colonies, most importantly the right to have more than one child per couple (polygamous relationships scaled, of course, but for odd numbers whether the extra was allowed depended on gene selection), and the Palaidian Empire would expand.

But now Gavra had no idea whether any of those planets to which Observers would normally be sent were under this being's protection. She found that she could not in good conscience send out Observers when there was a very real chance of death for them. Already the Council was having to go to great lengths and expense to keep the families of the thousand soldiers who died quiet--if the news broke, they knew it could well overthrow the system of government that had served Palaidia in good stead for billions of cycles.

So she did the only thing she could do, a thing she hadn't done since she was less than a tenth-cycle old, her invulnerability hadn't fully developed and she'd skinned her knee when she fell while learning to fly. She cried.

Oibva had of course tried to comfort her telepathically, but she'd just shut her mind off and, in the silence of her office, bawled her lungs out.

At least, she did until she felt a strong pair of hands massaging her shoulders. She immediately stopped sobbing and prepared to throw the interloper into the sun.

"Now now," said a chiding voice from behind her, "don't be impulsive like that. Listen to what I've got to say." Gavra no longer felt the hands as a blurry form appeared in the chair across her desk. She heated her eyes to clear them, and the thought of blasting the other's torso into its constituent particles crossed her mind.

"Don't bother with that," said the stranger. "I'm just as proof against it as you are."

"And who exactly are you?" asked Gavra.

"Oh! How rude of me. I'm--"

"--God," finished Gavra, not recognizing her from her encounter with the other five, and having just read a report that the most advanced non-Palaidian civilization known to her people had seemingly stagnated since its last visit.

"Yes. I'm God. But call me Sarah." The name sounded strange to Gavra.

"Sarah," she repeated, expecting to have difficulty pronouncing it but finding that it came quite naturally to her.

"Yes. I am, as you may have guessed, from the planet you tested and that you, your companion and her strike force destroyed after I kept bringing all of your subjects back to life. As for the name, it is from Hebrew."

Gavra felt a bit sickened by the reminder that she still knew every language from Earth. "Yes, I surmised that. I imagine you were rather displeased with what I did?"

"Not particularly. Oh, destroying the planet was a bit much, but that was easily repairable. No, I wanted to speak with you on other matters."

"What other matters?"

"First, that your wholesale slaughter will stop."

Gavra got defensive. "It's not slaughter. It's testing."

Sarah ignored her comment. "Second, that every planet is now under my protection." Gavra went white.

"Third, that the threat my daughters and their lovers made was empty."

"Empty? How?"

"Your Observers won't be killed for going to other planets. Hell, you can demolish every planet around and I'll just bring them back. I'm not going to allow Palaidia to become militaristic--after all, with Oibva--oh, don't look so shocked that I know her name, Gavra, or yours--on the Council, the military have a plurality--but when I can erase all evidence of you folks having a spot of fun I'm not going to stop it."

"Fun? If you think that Observing or calling in military strikes is fun you should use your powers to become more knowledgeable about Palaidians. We take it quite seriously."

"I know, but from now on it will basically be for fun. You're under my protection as much as anyone else, and I won't allow a species to advance far enough to challenge you--or, if I do, I'll see to it that you meet on friendly terms. The last thing I want is two races of immortal beings able to travel across the universe in the blink of an eye engaged in all-out war."

"Not so immortal," Gavra said bitterly.

"Well obviously I can kill you. But I've since punished my daughters for what they did to your soldiers, who, you may be pleased to know, are alive again and safe with their families."

"Nothing much. I took away their ability to digest anything instantly right after they'd eaten a good thousand people each. They'll feel bloated for a few days and then I'll probably take mercy on them."

She loved flying through black holes now, but she was always careful to just skirt through, just enough to feel the wonderful gravitational pull that she--but not light--could escape. Even so, she could still remember the first time she hit one, almost not escaping because she didn't know what she had encountered, and then the time that she had tested herself to see how close she could get to the singularity and had almost fallen past the point from which she could escape. For all that Amanda had insisted that her children would have a normal life, she found the urge to use her powers to give them a very good life irresistible.

While Matthew and Mary went through the usual phases of development, they were extremely precocious. They got the usual battery of inoculations, but Amanda used her powers to make them proof against all diseases, not merely imperfectly so against only some. When they were still very young, Amanda arranged to win a huge lottery jackpot, despite not needing money, and also founded a company that made many revolutionary devices.

It didn't take long for those devices to completely supplant everything that had gone before them, partly because of their amazing efficiency and partly because, being created by Amanda's powers, they had no actual production cost, allowing her to sell them cheaply. Her company showed incredible profits quarter after quarter and when she took the company public, after only a year of operation, the stock price quadrupled after only a day of trading.

Some of the devices became household fixtures, such as the instant washing machine and instant dishwasher. The collapsible and convertible TV--able to be a small handheld screen, a huge seventy-inch plasma TV, or split into parts with its own projector and speakers to watch movies as if you were in a theatre--similarly became ubiquitous, and every gamer got at least one universal computer, capable of running any program written for any operating system or game console ever created, complete with a guaranteed ultrafast, unlimited bandwidth internet connection (completely secure against outside intrusion, except for alerting law enforcement when users did things which Amanda did not tolerate). The stasis fridge, which kept food and drinks in the condition they were in when put in there (whether frozen or steaming hot) similarly supplanted all other such products. Every car in the world was, within a year, powered by the company's engine, which ran by taking in air, filtering the harmful components, converting those to pure energy and expelling clean air. (Amanda put in a failsafe so that when the concentration of toxic gases dropped below the supposedly necessary threshold, the engines would switch to being run each by a minute sliver of her own power.) Amanda, however, refused all media interviews and held no official title with the company, leaving it run, in theory, by Amia, Cressida, Irene, Emily and Carol, the three humans not really understanding what went on but satisfied with the huge salaries they commanded. Amia handled the media deftly, easily deflecting them from questions about the company's production processes and research and development, claiming trade secrets.

Rodger held down his day job, but used the comparatively meagre income as he saw fit, except for being careful never to come home drunk or otherwise incapacitated.

Amanda and Rodger did not send Matthew and Mary to preschool, Amanda preferring to tutor them herself, but did send them to a prestigious private school for kindergarten, where their teacher regularly praised how intelligent and well-behaved they were.

The school offered education all the way through the twelfth grade, but Rodger convinced Amanda that it would be beneficial for their children to attend public schools for the remainder of their education. They continued to excel in their new setting, though Amanda watched them like a hawk from afar to ensure that they did not draw the attention of any bullies.

After eight years of elementary and middle school, high school hit. Amanda had timed her children's physical development, and it was just as they hit high school that they blossomed.

Matthew, as Amanda intended, took an interest in football and basketball. He grew quickly to a towering seven-foot-six and was very fast and nimble, with pinpoint aim, quickly earning him places on both teams as starting quarterback and starting centre. He carried himself with confidence, but never used his social stature to bully other students into doing as he pleased, instead helping as he could and sticking up for other kids against bullies. He wasn't even out of his junior year before many top athletic schools had all but promised him full-ride scholarships.

Mary's growth was not as rapid, but she became the undisputed beauty of her school. While Matthew's development had mostly ended after a few months into his freshman year, Mary continued to grow, overtopping her brother in the summer after their sophomore year. Amanda, remembering what it was like not to be particularly beautiful, ensured the same would not happen to Mary, giving her a perfect face, perfect smile and perfect body, from rich chestnut hair dropping to the small of her back, a clear complexion, breasts that, even once she had reached her full height of nine feet only a week before graduation, were still proportionally far larger than any other student's, an amazingly thin waist and a huge ass. Sofia sighed. Whenever any sort of party was held, Sofia would be hounded by many young men trying to woo her. They didn't seem to realise that the normal female attention they got was due to their immense riches, and that that sort of thing doesn't really work when trying to impress a Princess, who's never known any life but one of luxury. They seemed to think they were entitled to any girl they wanted, which led to her having to avoid most of them whenever possible.

----------------

Eventually Lascinda and Razef did get up, and the Queen laid in bed, watching her guard captain get dressed.
"Something catch your eye?" He asked her. "You know, it's rude to stare."
"Yes, that serpent between your legs," Lascinda replied. "I'm thinking about all the venom it infected me with last night."
"It still has plenty of venom inside, if you want it."
"It would be my pleasure." Lascinda smiled, and knelt on her bed in front of Razef, who walked up to her. He was wearing just his cuirass, so his penis was still hanging free. Lascinda took it in her hand, and then engulfed it with her mouth.
"Oh...Oh yeah..." Razef moaned. "Oh that's good..."

Before long, Razef spurted his seed into Lascinda's mouth, which she swallowed. She licked him clean, and pulled away.
"If I may say so Lascinda, you're rather good at that," Razef said.
"Fellatio is a skill that, once learned, one never forgets," Lascinda smiled, and kissed the tip of his softening dick. "Though while we're dealing out compliments, it may interest you to know that your endowment is significantly larger than that of my husband."

134331111221122.content:
A few nights later, Sofia was asleep in bed, when she heard a noise. She opened one eye, and saw her balcony door opening, and a figure walk through. She sat up, and the figure quickly turned to her, brandishing a knife.
"If you value your life, I suggest you don't scream," the figure said. He then turned, and started rummaging through one of Sofia's drawers.
"If you are looking for jewels, then I'm afraid you are mistaken," she told him. "That draw contains my undergarments."
"Then where are they!?" The robber asked sharply, causing Sofia to jump.
"There is a jewellery box on that table over there," Sofia pointed across the room, and the robber went to get the jewels.

"May I ask though, what would happen if I were to scream?" she asked him.
"Then I would ram this knife through your heart!" The robber replied.
"While you may do that, it would not benefit you in the slightest," she told him bluntly.
"Of course it fucking would!" He shouted.
"No, it wouldn't," Sofia told him. "Outside my bedroom are two armed guards. If I were to scream, they would burst into here, and hold you at sword point. At which point my mother would be woken to deal with you. If I am dead, she will show far less mercy than if I am alive. As such...."

Sofia let out a deafening scream, and within seconds, the guards burst in, brandishing their swords.
"Your highness, are you-!?" One of them asked in a panic, before they saw the robber. They held their swords up to him.
"Drop the sword!" The second guard shouted.
"Don't move, or we'll gut you!" The first guard shouted. "Now get up and walk!" The robber stood up, and they guided him out of the room, with Sofia following closely behind.
"Your highness," said the first guard. "If you must follow us, please keep your distance."

The guards took the robber down to the dungeons, and soon, another robber was brought down to the same cell, with the Queen soon following.
"Sofia, go back to bed," Lascinda said to her daughter. "This is grown-up business."
"Mother, that man broke into my bedroom and threatened me at knife-point," Sofia said. "I feel I deserve to be here."
"Fine, but don't complain if you don't like what you see," Lascinda relented.

The Queen turned to the prisoners, and her eyes widened.
"Hello Lascinda," said the one who'd broken into Sofia's room.
"Kill them. Kill them now!" Lascinda ordered. "Turn them into dust!"
"Mother, what are you saying?" Sofia asked in horror. "That is not what God would want."
"I like her," said the second robber. "Hey kid, you'd make a much better Queen than her."
"Don't you dare talk to her like that!" Lascinda shouted. "Captain Horkmir, kill them now."

"Your majesty, with all due respect, would it not be wiser to wait until morning?" Horkmir said.
"Captain, I think you're forgetting how dangerous these men are!" Lascinda shouted. "They must be punished for their crimes!"
"I agree ma'am, but would a public execution tomorrow morning not be more fitting?" Horkmir suggested. "The people deserve to see justice being done."
"Very well Captain," Lascinda relented. "I shall return to bed now, but please ensure that these scum are given no food or drink."
"As you wish ma'am."

Sofia and Lascinda left the dungeons, and walked back towards their bedrooms.
"Mother, may I assume you knew those men?" Sofia asked her mother.
"Sofia, those are the men who murdered your father," Lascinda told Sofia, who was shocked.
"Father's....murderers..." she mumbled.
"Yes. Which I why I was so keen for vengeance on them. You know how reluctant I normally am to put people to death."
"Even so, are you sure it is the right thing to do?"
"Sofia, when you get to my age you'll understand. Now go back to bed."
"Yes mother..."

1343311112211221.content:
Sofia was unsure as to whether or not she should attend the execution. On the one hand, she wanted to see justice done for her father, but on the other hand, she'd never been one for gore. In the end, she decided to stay in the palace. Harson went to the execution, which Sofia understood. After all, Harson had recently turned 3 when their father had died, so he probably had fond memories of him, but he didn't like to talk about it. Sofia stayed in her room, writing the essay about Janosian history that her tutor had set her as homework. She scrambled through her brain to remember facts about the fall of Shinson, nearly 2000 years ago. While she had a deep interest in the history of her world, remembering lots of facts about minor events was very difficult. As she wrote, she saw a flash of light, followed almost instantly by the sound of thunder.
"Lightning..." She thought. "And it must be close..."

Sofia needed a break, so she headed down to the kitchen to get herself a drink. On the way down, she passed her mother and brother, who'd just returned from the execution. Her mother didn't even acknowledge her however, and simply headed straight up to her room.
"Is Mother okay?" Sofia asked her brother.
"She's been like that ever since those murderers got their heads chopped off," Harson replied. "She didn't say a word to me on the way back."
"She's probably just emotional. After all, those are the men who murdered father."
"Whatever. I'm going to my room. Don't disturb me."

Harson turned to walk away, but Sofia shouted after him.
"Harson!" The Prince stopped in his tracks. "Do you remember Father?"
"Of course I do," Harson replied.
"What do you remember?"
"Not much. I remember his smile. And how he'd sit in the big chair in the living room, take me on his lap, and tell me stories. And...I remember one day...asking mother where he was. She just cuddled me, and told me he wasn't coming home, but that he was happy. Then she told me that she wouldn't ever let anything happen to me. I think she was trying to hold back her tears."

Harson headed up to his room, and Sofia thought about his words. She wished she'd been able to meet her father, but he'd died before she was born. He'd never even known that her mother was pregnant with her. But she was sure that he was looking down on his widowed wife, smiling at how well she was doing as Queen without him.

------------

"That stupid woman!" Amanda shouted, laying down on her sofa. "Why couldn't she just do what she was told!?"
"Please calm down, My Lady," Cressida begged, sitting on the chair next to her.
"Yes My Lady, she was just very angry at these men," Amia said calmly. "They did kill her husband after all. I know if anyone ever did anything to Achré, I'd be furious."
"She knows that she rules by my will," Amanda said angrily. "She even got the order directly from me! Does she not have any brains? I'm half tempted to make that lightning storm I sent down there actually hit her."

"My lady, would you like a drink to calm yourself down?" Amia asked, pouring God some juice. She gulped it down.
"Could we have not simply explained to her the reason for ordering their pardon?" Cressida asked.
"No, that would have resulted in the Queen asking questions for which we do not have the answer," Amia replied. "To this day I can't work out why the God of the time made those boys kill the King of Janosia. When I asked him about it, he told me that it was none of my concern."

"I suppose the Lord really did work in mysterious ways," Cressida said.
"He was normally very good at taking my advice, but sometimes he'd just do something rash on his own," Amia said, clearly thinking back. "Like the time he sent those plagues down, just to free a few of his followers from slavery."
"The plagues of Egypt," Amanda said. "Surely it was right for him to want to free his followers?"
"Yes, but there are better ways of doing things," Amia shook her head. "I mean, he sent Uriel down to kill every first-born son in Egypt, which set their breeding capabilities back quite a bit. And then there was the huge volcano he made erupt about 70,000 thousand years ago, and almost wiped out your species. You know why he did that? Because someone at the time declared himself to be a God, and a group of people dared to worship him. He was petty. He only listened to my advice when the mood struck him."

"This though is why you shouldn't be mad at the Queen, my Lady," Cressida said to her. "You wanted her to spare them, because she was punishing them for something they'd done by divine command. But you didn't actually tell her this. You simply ordered her to pardon them."
"It shouldn't matter," Amanda said. "At her coronation, she took an oath to serve God, did she not? That includes obeying all orders without question."
"You're starting to sound like Barry," Amia said to her, worriedly.
"It's fine, because I actually take your advice," Amanda replied. "Which is all the more reason to have done as I commanded. The order was advised by the most intelligent being in the universe."

"I remember going to see her after her husband's funeral, in order to re-affirm the agreements that the two of them had agreed to after their coronation," Amia told them both. "I couldn't look her in the eye the whole time, knowing that we were to blame for her sadness. I could sense the embryo growing inside her at the time, but I was forbidden from mentioning it to her."

-----------------

"You sent for me mother?" Sofia asked, walking into her mother's bedroom. She was laid on her bed, and Sofia could tell that she'd been crying.
"Sofia, come and sit with me please," Lascinda said. Sofia laid down next to her mother, who wrapped her arms around her.
"Mother, what's wrong?"
"Sofia, I've done something very bad. I have sinned against God."
"Mother, I'm sure that whatever you've done, God will forgive you."
"I'm not so sure about that...Last night, God appeared to me in my dreams. She ordered me to spare the lives of your father's murders. And I refused. I refused because I wanted to see justice done for him."

Sofia was shocked at this.
"Mother, you cannot disobey God!" She said in shock.
"I know, I know..." Lascinda cried. "This lightning storm began the instant the axe hit the men's heads. I knew I'd made a horrible mistake. God is angry at me, and I don't know what to do."
"Pray for forgiveness."
"I have been doing! But I've gotten no response."

Lascinda hugged her daughter for while longer.
"You know, I remember when your grandfather died," Lascinda said. "On his deathbed, he told your father and I that we would soon be visited by God, in order to re-affirm an agreement that had existed for nearly 5 centuries. We were both shocked. God arrived after our coronation. He sat on a golden throne, with his archangel Amia on his right hand. We were on our knees the whole time, and it was a very humbling experience. Then after your father died, I didn't know how I was going to cope. He'd always done most of the ruling, while I looked after your brother. Lots of people began to oppose my rule. They said that I should just abdicate. Well, I was hardly going to let a 3-year-old boy take the throne, was I? Not long after the funeral, God and his angel returned, not looking a day older than when last we met. And then I found out I was pregnant again. I was at my wit's end with stress."

"Were we a burden on you, mother?" Sofia asked.
"No, of course not," Lascinda replied. "To be honest, I was glad of some company that wasn't always bowing to me."

1343311112212.content:
When God and her angels had left, Sofia headed back to her room, where she found James in it.
"Ah your highness, I've just finished preparing your bath," he said.
"Thank you James," Sofia said. "Could you bring me some tea and biscuits please?"
"Of course your highness," James said, and left.
Sofia let out a long sigh of relaxation as she got into the bath. Today had been a rather interesting day for her. Her tutor had told her that she needed to improve her knowledge of the Aatii and Swaylock languages. The planet Janosia was inhabited by three intelligent species; Sofia's own people, the Fuso, were almost human, only varying in the layout of their internal organs, most notably the presence of a second stomach; one for solids, and one for liquids. The Aatii were a race of birdmen, with beaks on their faces above their mouths, and wings attatched to their arms. The Swalock meanwhile were a race of fishmen, entirely covered in scales, and with long fins on their limbs for swimming. All 3 species had their own language, and as a member of Janosia's royal family, Sofia was expected to be fluent in all 3.

Of course, the highlight of her day had been meeting God. Her mother had always told her stories about God, about how her great-great-grandfather had been so desperate to end the wars that he had shouted to the sky for help, only to find a man stood next to him, saying he would help to stop the wars, in return for being worshipped. You see, prior to that, Janosia as a whole had been largely religion-free, apart from a few isolated tribes. Introducing religion to the planet was hard for the King, especially since God had said that they weren't allowed to tell the people about the deal they'd made. Sofia had always been fascinated by the idea of God, but she'd always had some doubt as to whether the stories were true or not. When she'd met God she'd expected her to be terrifying, and as demanding as Harson, but instead she was soft-spoken, and very polite. Her voice made her feel safe, although she was still rather nervous in her presence.

Sofia got out of the bath, and dried herself off. She headed back into her bedroom, and saw that James had left a tray of tea and biscuits on her bedside table. Sofia put her pyjamas on, and laid in bed, drinking her tea while she read a book. After a while, Sofia began to hear a voice in her head.
"Sofia," it said.
"Your holiness?" Sofia asked, slightly scared.
"Don't be scared," Amanda said in Sofia's head. "May I come in?"
"What do you mean?"
"Your bedroom. May I come in?"
"Uh...yes..." Suddenly there was a bright light, and Sofia saw Amanda stood at the foot of her bed. Sofia scrambled to get on her knees, though she seemed unsure as to whether she should bow on the bed, or get off it and bow on the floor.
"Relax Sofia, you need not bow to me," Amanda told her.
"Thank you your holiness," Sofia said. "Though, may I ask a question?"
"Of course."
"Why did you ask my permission before coming in here?"
"Because although I have infinite authority over the universe, I thought it would be rude to enter here without permission."

Hearing this put Sofia at ease, knowing that God respected her.
"Would you like a biscuit your holiness?" Sofia, still feeling slightly odd about offerring God a biscuit.
"Yes thank you," Amanda said. She took a biscuit, and sat down on a chair next to Sofia's bed. "But I must speak with you. I have a task for you."
"Simply speak and I will obey," Sofia said.
"Please Sofia, do not feel that I am forcing you into this. I want you to only do this if you want to."
"Of course, though I'm sure that whatever it is I will be happy to do."
"Sofia, your mother and brother will soon die."
"What!? How!?"
"A terrible plague is coming, which will kill millions all over Janosia, including your mother and brother."

Sofia was almost in tears at this revelation.
"But why?" She asked. "Have we displeased you?"
"No Sofia, this is not my doing," Amanda replied. "This plague is entirely natural."
"Then will you save us from it?"
"No."
"But why?"
"Because though this plague will do much damage, through it will come much good. All over the planet, there are groups who have never truly given up after the wars, and still fight amongst themselves. Left alone, their fighting will eventually spread all over the world, until a second great war begins, which will last for centuries."
"That's terrible..." Sofia said, crying over the thought of losing her family. Amanda put her arms around her to comfort her.
"It is okay," Amanda told her softly. "The plague will kill off many of the war-mongering members of these groups. Those who are left will be less keen on the idea of war, but will not stop without intervention. By this point you will have become Queen, and I want you to travel to these groups, and act as a peace negotiator for them."

Sofia laid in Amanda's arms, crying for a while, before she spoke again.
"I...I want to do it," she said. "I want to bring peace to this planet."
"Your people will thank you Sofia," Amanda said. "And I promise, your mother and brother will receive eternal life with me when they die. They will be happy forever."
"Thank you your holiness," Sofia said, still crying, though not as much.
"Don't worry Sofia, this will all be for the best," Amanda said. "I only ask that you not tell anyone about what I have told you."
"Yes your holiness."

"Lord, as we deliver the souls of our beloved Queen and Prince to you," said the Priest at Harson and Lascinda's funeral. "We ask you to forgive them their sins, and grant them eternal life with you. Amen."
"Amen," chorused the crowds. Sofia was sat nearby, trying to hold back her tears, figuring that it wouldn't be right for the new Queen to be seen crying. On her death bed, Lascinda had requested a public burial, so Sofia had honoured her mother's wishes by holding it out in the Janosian capital, with anyone welcome. The coronation was due to be held immediately afterwards, so Sofia was in her best dress.
"You can cry if you want you know," a voice said. Sofia turned to see God sat next to her.
"You've got some nerve coming here," the new Queen said.
"Excuse me your majesty?" James asked.
"Only you can see me," Amanda said.

"I know you're mad at me Sofia, and you have every right to be," Amanda said. "But please understand that I can't just go around saving people. Well I can, but then what's the point in free-will? Sometimes, bad things just happen to good people. But I promise you they're happy now, and will be forever and ever, You're mother was beloved by the people of Janosia, and they'll love you too if you are able to save them from war."
"But why don't you just do it?" Sofia whispered. "We're worshipping you like you said. I thought you said you'd protect us."
"I am protecting you by telling you how to stop the war from breaking out," Amanda replied. "If you choose you ignore my advice, then that's your fault, not mine. Anyway, your public is waiting."

Sofia got up, walked to the front, and knelt before the priest.
"Sofia, daughter of Lascinda III and Sargo V," the priest said. "Do you accept the responsibilities being bestowed upon you? To rule with honestly and humility, for the good of Janosia?"
"I do," Sofia said.
"Then I hereby crown you, Queen Sofia I," the priest said, putting a crown on Sofia's head, to loud cheers from the crowd. Sofia moved up to a pedestal.
"My people," Sofia said, addressing the crowd. "These are trying times. This plague is devastating our land, but we must be strong. I have faith that God will not let us be wiped out. I know my mother would not want us to mourn her, for she would want us to focus on keeping our land safe. In order to do this, I will be visiting several groups in the outlands in order to form an alliance with them."

After the ceremony was over, Sofia made her way back to her room.
"I take it you'll do it then?" Amanda asked, appearing on Sofia's bed.
"Yes, but only to help my people," Sofia replied.
"Sofia, I'm really trying to help you," Amanda said.
"Just leave me alone," Sofia said.

134331111221211.content:
Although Sofia's family officially ruled the planet Janosia, they only officially ruled about 3 quarters of the planet. The rest was a series of snowy mountains whom the Janosian government largely ignored, due to the harsh terrain, and only being inhabited by several small tribes. Sofia was heading there to make peace between the Linto and Grongi tribes, who were currently on the verge of war, which, according to God, would eventually spread across the planet. It was a week-long journey through the cold, harsh terrain. It was nighttime, and Sofia was in the back of her carriage, in a special section filled with mattresses, pillows, cushions, duvets and anything else to help Sofia sleep in relative comfort and warmth. If you were to look in, you'd see the 16, nearly 17, year-old girl if you looked hard enough past everything she was wrapped in.

Sofia was laid trying to get to sleep, but she just couldn't. Part of it was because of the cold breeze she could feel coming in through the cracks in the cart, which she tried to avoid by moving a pillow in front of it. But most of her insomnia was coming from all that had happened recently. Meeting God, and being given this great task. She'd never anticipated becoming Queen, so to have this thrust upon her so suddenly was a bit daunting. She's never realised how much work her mother actually had to do. And while everyone else had lost their Queen and Prince, she's lost her mother and brother. As much as Harson had annoyed her, she still loved him, and she was sad to see him go. And her mother had always been a source of wisdom, and support when she was sad, and to have her gone was heartbreaking.

"I feel your pain," said a voice from behind Sofia. She turned to the entrance hatch, through which she saw a man, dressed in all white. Though the hatch was open, Sofia could not feel the cold.
"Hello, your majesty," the man said in an almost mocking way.
"Who are you?" Sofia asked. "Are you one of God's angels?"
"Indeed I am," the angel replied. "You can call me Damien."
"Here to give me more tasks? To tell me more of my loved ones are going to die!?" Sofia asked, anger evident in her voice.
"Now now Sofia," Damien said. "You and I are not so different. We both dislike God."
"It's not that I dislike God..."
"Oh don't give me that Sofia, you hate that she didn't help your family, or stop the plague. And I hate not her, but the divine hierarchy. You know, the god before her was a tyrant, who demanded worship of the whole universe. Anyone who didn't worship him would be damned to hell instantly, and sometimes he'd just pick random people and damn them to remind people who was boss."
"That's terrible...but I don't remember that?"
"Of course you don't. That woman you now call God erased all memory of this. But what's to stop this from happening again sometime in the future? Nothing. I am part of a group of several angels and mortals who seek to overthrow God. By putting ourselves in charge, we can prevent this suffering from ever happening again. So I ask you Sofia, to join us, and save the universe from abuse of divine power.

Sofia was confused. She had always been told that God was all good, and while she'd disagreed with some of the things that God had done recently, she trusted in her judgement, that it would all work out for the best.
"No...I won't do it!" Sofia said.
"Foolish mortal, you will pay for disobeying me!" Damien said in a demonic voice. "You will burn now, and when we are in charge, you and your people will suffer for your insolence!" Sofia was terrified, as she felt her body heat up dramatically, and fire form in Damien's hands, aimed at her. Sofia cowered as far away as she could possibly get, and was about to beg for mercy, when a bright light engulfed Damien, and he was suddenly in chains. Sofia then saw Amia and Cressida appear next to him, grabbing him.
"Damien, I'm disappointed," Amanda said, appearing next to Sofia. "Did you really think I wouldn't be watching her?"
"Damn you, you'll doom the universe!" Damien hissed. "It's because of you that the universe will suffer at the hands of you and your successors!"
"Amia, Cressida, please take him away. I'll deal with him later," Amanda commanded.
"Yes Goddess," the two angels replied, and disappeared with Damien.

"I'm sorry Sofia," Amanda said, turning to the Queen. "I should have expected that someone would come to tempt you. They love to do that with people whom I have visited, and with you being a Queen, you were too much to resist."
"Who's 'they'?" Sofia asked, still a bit shaken up.
"Followers of Satan, who believe that I am not fit for office," Amanda replied. "Even though Satan was long since banished to his own personal hell, there are still people who follow his beliefs and try to overthrow me."
"So..when he was talking about an evil God that forced worship, he was lying?"
"That...was true. But that was a one-off event that has since been fixed. And procedures have been put in place to ensure that it won't happen again. Now, you should get some sleep. You have a big day tomorrow."
"They won't come back will they?"
"No, I will protect you." Amanda then stood up, and left through the hatch, closing it as she did.

Sofia arrived at the main Grongi village, and was taken into a large conference room, where she saw the two leaders. Gresho, the Grongi leader, was glaring at her with obvious dislike. Meanwhile, the Linto leader Hersius looked as nervous as Sofia felt, and gave her a quick bow. Sofia sat down at the table.
"You've got some nerve demanding this meeting," Gresho said angrily.
"I did not demand anything," Sofia said. "I merely requested this meeting to attempt to bring peace to your to tribes. I'm sure that that is what the two of you want."
"No it's not!" Gresho shouted. "We must punish these Linto scum for the suffering that they've brought upon us!"
"We've done nothing!" Hersius protested.

"What do you think they did?" Sofia asked Gresho.
"They brought this plague upon us by asking their god to bring it upon us!" Gresho replied. "You should join us in punishing them for this!"
"We've not done anything of the sort!" Hersius protested. "We are a peaceful people, and we worship the same God as her majesty here does."
"Then you must both be punished!" Gresho shouted.
"Gresho, calm down," Sofia told him. "God is peaceful, and only seeks to help us. And anyway, you wouldn't stand a chance against us. Our armies are hundreds, perhaps thousands of times greater than yours. Incidentally, if I do not return within a week from now, they have instructions to march on this village and avenge me."

Sofia then picked up the glass of water that had been provided for her.
"Of course," she continued. "I have guards around me all day long, so the only way that anything could happen to me is, say, if there were some 'special' additives in this water." Sofia moved the glass to her lips.
"Wait!" Gresho interrupted her, taking the water from her hand. "Drink mine."

"Perhaps I was...a tad hasty," Gresho said. "We shall agree to end all hostility."
"Thank you," Sofia said.

Sofia left the negotiations proud of herself, knowing that she'd saved her world.

"I'm sorry, but she hasn't got long left," replied the doctor. "I'll leave you alone." The doctor left, and the royal family all sat with the ageing Queen. Sofia was now an old lady, and was at death's door. As she lay in bed, her family watched her, struggling to hold back their tears. There was Sofia's only child Prince Sargo, named after her own her own father, and who was fathered by Sofia's husband Herrji, who had died several years prior. Also there were Sargo's wife Eri, and their two children; 15-year-old daughter Princess Moune and 5-year-old son Prince Agri.
"Come on mother, don't die," Sargo said.
"I'm not afraid of death," Sofia said.
"But grandma, who will bake us cookies?" Agri asked.
"Your mother will have to do that now," Sofia replied.
"Hey, I'm a good cook!" Eri said.

"Mother...I can't let you go..." Sargo said. "I'm not ready to be king!"
"Sargo, I completely trust in the abilities that you and Eri possess," Sofia assured them. "God would not allow an unfit person to rule Janosia."

When he'd woken up, it had been morning, and before long he'd been examined by what he'd assumed was a doctor, and then given food, drink, and clothing. And now there was this beautiful girl, attempting to speak to him. She seemed to be in some sort of position of authority, perhaps royalty, so he'd bowed to her. He didn't understand a word she was saying, but her voice sounded lovely. She sat down on the bed, and gestured for him to sit with her, which he did.

"Io sono Sofia," she said. "E tu? Come ti chiami?" He gave her a blank look.
"Sofia," she said, pointing to herself, before to him. "E tu?"
"Largos," he said.
"Largos," she smiled. "Un buon nome. Dove venghi da?" He gave her another blank look.

Sofia sighed. This wasn't working. She was trying to work out where he was from, but if they didn't understand each-other, they weren't going to get very far.
"Es tut mir Leid," said Largos. "Dass wir einander nicht verstehen können. Ich möchte viel mit Ihnen sprechen." Sofia could tell that he wasn't speaking Aatii or Swaylock, the other 2 languages spoken on Janosia, aside from Fuso, Sofia's own language. Suddenly, there was a bright light, and Amanda appeared, with Amia and Cressida at either side of her. Sofia got on her knees, and Largos did so too, figuring that whoever can suddenly appear like that was to be feared.

"Vostra santità!" Sofia exclaimed. "È un onore."
"Rise Sofia, Largos," Amanda said, and Sofia did, Largos following. He was shocked though; he could understand this woman, and apparently the girl could too. Amia turned to him.
"Your surprise is to be expected," Amia said. "But know that we are not bound by barriers such as language. And, for now at least, neither are the two of you." Amanda waved her hand, and then the three of them vanished.

"What did she mean by that?" Sofia wondered out loud. Largos look at her, stunned.
"I...I understood you," Largos said to her.
"And I understand you!" Sofia said excitedly. They both sat down on the bed again.
"But how is this possible?" Largos asked, confused.
"Such is the power of God," Sofia explained.
"I do not understand, who is God?"
"That...will have to wait."

"So, I think more formal introductions are in order," Sofia said. "I am Queen Sofia I, daughter of Sargo V and Lascinda III. But you may simply call me "Sofia". After all, you are not technically one of my subjects. I rule over this whole planet, which is called "Janosia". And what about you? Where are you from?"
"Well, I'm Largos, a nobody," Largos replied. "My planet is called Akuman, and it is the capital of the Zenju Empire, which covers 12 galaxies. It is ruled over by a cruel Empress named Akina."
"How did you end up here?" Sofia asked.
"I...was foolish enough...to try and assassinate the Empress," Largos told her. "I managed to sneak into her birthday party, which was an achievement in itself. But I was easily caught. As a punishment, the Empress had my entire family burned alive in front of my eyes. Then, she had me put in that ship, and sent to my death. It's just luck I managed to crash here instead of running out of fuel in deep space."

"That's awful..." Sofia said. "But is this Empress really worthy of assassination?"
"I promise you, she is," Largos said. "She once had an entire planet burned in a fit of rage. She often takes people off of the streets, and either enslaves them, or just tortures them for fun."
"That is indeed horrible," Sofia said. "I can't imagine such horrors..."
"Which is why I need to leave," Largos said. "You have shown me great kindness. If the Empress discovers that I have survived here, she will come for me, and she will punish your world, either by enslavement, or destruction. I cannot put you in that danger."

"I will not let your Empress bully us," Sofia said firmly.
"Your majesty...Sofia...I fear that you under-estimate her power," Largos warned her. "She is not to be trifled with."
"Largos, this planet is protected by forces beyond comprehension. We have no need to worry," Sofia assured him. "And anyway, how would you leave? Your vessel is destroyed."
"Sofia, you are Queen, and therefore have power of life and death over your subjects, correct?"
"Yes but...what are you suggesting?"
"Sofia, please have me executed. It is the only way to make your planet safe."
"I refuse. I will not have an innocent person executed. We will stand strong against any opposition."
"Then you doom yourselves."

Author's Note:

Okay, so I wanted to express the fact that Sofia and Largos were speaking different languages to each-other, which isn't easy to do, especially since neither of them are actually speaking English, they're speaking their planets' languages. For this, I decided to keep switching between their perspectives. When it's their perspective, we see their dialogue in English, and the other person's in a foreign language. As luck would have it, I have a decent knowledge of 2 foreign languages; Italian and German. I gave Sofia Italian, due to the fact that she and a lot of the other Janosians have Italian-sounding names, which was intentional, as well as the fact that it sounds a lot more graceful than German, which I feel fits Sofia's character. So Largos got German. I've not bothered including translations of what they say, because honestly most of it's either not important, blatantly obvious, or later stated. If you're really desperate, Google Translate can get you close-enough English translations.

134331111221211122211.content:
That evening, Sofia was laid in bed, not sleeping. She was too busy thinking about Largos. She'd refused to have him executed, despite his warnings about the Empress' wrath. She trusted in God's protection, though she'd be lying if she'd said it didn't scare her a little. As she laid there, her bed was surrounded by a bright light.
"Y...your holiness?" Sofia asked meekly. Soon the light faded, and Sofia saw that she was no longer in her bedroom. She was in what appeared to be a large throne room, though it seemed a lot more high tech than she was used to. Either side of the long room was filled with a line of guards carrying weaponry which seemed strange to Sofia, which Earthlings might identify as guns. At the end of the room was throne, but Sofia didn't get a good look at its occupier before she felt herself being grabbed.
"Get up peasant!" Shouted one of the guards that grabbed her, and pulled her out of bed, dragging her towards the throne. At this point, Sofia was glad she slept in her pyjamas.

Sofia was thrown down in front of the throne, bruising her body. She started to stand up, but she felt a large rod hit her, sending powerful electricity through her, sending her back down onto her knees.
"On your knees girl!" Shouted one of the guards. "You have not been given permission to stand."
"So you are the ruler of this planet?" Sofia heard the throne's owner ask her.
"I am Sofia, 538th of my royal line, and 56th ruler of Janosia," Sofia replied, trying to catch her breath from the shock. "May I assume that you are Empress Akina of the Zenju Empire?"
"My my, she's not totally stupid," Akina said in a patronising tone. "Whatever happened to the primatives that worshipped us as Gods? I do so enjoy those."

"I'll have you know I received education from the finest tutors on Janosia," Sofia said proudly. "I'd hardly consider myself 'primitive'."
"Don't talk back to the Empress!" A guard shouted, thrusting out the shock rod again.
"Enough!" Akina shouted before he made contact. "This girl intrigues me. Bring her to me." Sofia felt herself be grabbed again, and be carried up the stairs, until she was thrown down again right in front of the throne.

"If I were to attempt to stand again, would I be shocked?" Sofia asked the Empress.
"Those who do not conform must be punished," Akina replied. "Tell me Sofia, what do your subjects call you?"
"Why, "Your Majesty" of course," Sofia replied.
"And why do they do this?"
"Because they consider it respectful, and I do not wish to disagree."
"And what do you do when they do not call you this?"
"Nothing. I never demand it of them."
"Then you are weak. It is a wonder that you have managed to keep your hold on your people at all."
"My mother taught me kindness. Perhaps you should try it too."

At this, the guards started to approach Sofia with their shock rods.
"No, just pick her up," Akina ordered, and the guards grabbed Sofia, and held her stood up. The Queen finally got a good look at this Empress. She looked the same species as Sofia, but she had bright red skin, and a thin, snake-like tongue.
"Let me tell you what's going to happen," Akina said arrogantly. "That fool Largos is going to be re-captured, and subjected to agonising torture for the rest of his days. And if you don't start showing some more respect, I might decide to let you join him. Then, my army shall invade your world, and I shall make a wonderful speech informing your people of their Queen's suffering, and that some of them will become slaves, while millions more will be slaughtered. The rest will be allowed to live on as my subjects, on the latest planet to be a part of the Zenju Empire."

"And let me tell you what's going to happen," Sofia said, almost as arrogantly. "You are going to leave this planet, and never return. Or I shall be forced to call on this planet's protection."
"Foolish girl, do you really think that your soldiers can even scratch mine?" Akina laughed. "If I wanted, I could have your planet turned to a smoldering wreck within hours. You wouldn't be the first to incur my wrath in this way."
"Our protection is infinitely more powerful than you and I," Sofia told her. "I promise you that it's in your best interest to not incur its wrath."
"Enough, I grow tired of this," Akina laid back on her throne. "Disintegrate her." Sofia didn't know what that meant, but it didn't sound good. The guards grabbed her, and threw her down the stairs. She heard guns charging, and then nothing.
134331111221211122211.title: The Queen Meets The Empress

1343311112212111222111.content:
The next moment, Sofia found herself in what appeared to be a lavish bedroom.
"Hello Sofia," Amanda said. Sofia looked, and saw Amanda sat opposite her on the sofa, with Amia and Cressida on either side of her. She quickly bowed her head.
"Relax Sofia, you've done enough bowing for today," Amanda said. "Are you comfortable?"
"Um...yes, thank you," Sofia replied. She was totally naked, and sat in what appeared to be her favourite arm chair from the palace. "Where is this place?"
"This Sofia, is my bedroom in my palace in heaven," Amanda replied. "Tea and biscuits?"
"Thank you," Sofia replied, taking pouring some tea into what she noticed was her favourite mug.
"You should be honoured," Amia told her. "Not even we are allowed in here without God's permission."

"Your holiness, if this is heaven, does that mean that I am...well..." Sofia asked.
"Dead? Oh yeah, definitely," Amanda replied.
"Akina's guards disintegrated you," Cressida said. "As deaths go, there are far more painful ways to go."
"Of course, we can't have you staying dead," Amia informed her. "You have no children, and we don't wish for your uncle to get the throne."

"What about the Zenju army?" Sofia asked, worried. "They made such great threats..."
"Sofia, as you said yourself, I am infinitely more powerful than the Zenju Empire," Amanda assured her. She waved her hand, and her TV screen switched on, to show the Zenju fleet being attacked by a swarm of angels. They were all wiped out, apart from the mother ship. Thousands of angels walked on board, with the archangels Gabriel and Dorothea leading them. As they walked towards the Empress, her guards were paralyzed, unable to move. 3 of them stood in front of Akina, defending her, but Gabriel and Dorothea simply raised their hands, and threw them against the walls.
"I demand to know who you are!" Akina shouted.
"We come in the name of her holiness, the Lady God Almighty," Gabriel told her sternly.
"Our lady has instructed us to spare you, with the warning that if you should ever return to this planet, she will not be so merciful," Dorothea said, a slightly evil grin on her face. "And we've seen how she punishes people. You don't want to anger her."
"Who is this "God", who is too much of coward to face me herself!?" Akina demanded. "Bring her to me!"
"She is too busy comforting Queen Sofia," Dorothea told the Empress. "Now go, before her mercy runs out."

Amanda switched the screen off, and turned back to Sofia.
"They shall not threaten you anymore," Amia told her.
"I thank you," Sofia said graciously. "And I'm sure Largos will thank you."
"I am giving you exclusive permission to for you to tell him what happened tonight," Amanda said. "You may reveal the extent of our arrangement if you like. Now then, I believe it's time you left. Leave your mug here."

Sofia stood up, and was led out of Amanda's bedroom. Through the corridors they walked, before they reached an elevator, which they got in. Amia pressed a few buttons, and Sofia felt them going down.
"You should put these on," Cressida said, handing Sofia her pyjamas, which were neatly folded. "Unless you feel it would be proper for the Queen to go streaking."
"No, perhaps it wouldn't be," Sofia blushed, putting her pyjamas on, along with her slippers.
"Don't worry," Cressida assured her. "They won't get dirty."
"Dirty?" Sofia asked, confused. "Why? Where are we going?" The elevator stopped, and the doors opened. Sofia saw what appeared to be nighttime wilderness.
"Planet Janosia," Cressida said. "Please take all personal belongings with you."

Sofia walked out slowly.
"Well, thank you!" Sofia said to them, but as she turned around, she realised that there was no trace they'd ever been there. Sofia walked a bit, and realised she was on the road leading up to the palace. It was a little bit difficult in the dark, especially in the blizzard that was raging, making various parts of Sofia's body numb.
"Halt! Who goes there!" Shouted Leksho, who was on duty by the gate.
"Leksho, it's me," Sofia said as she approached.
"Your majesty!" The two guards exclaimed. "What are you doing here? The whole town's on high alert looking for you!"
"It's a long story," Sofia told them. "But first, would you be so kind as to escort me to the palace please?"
"Yes your majesty," Leksho obeyed. He escorted Sofia back to the palace, where Horkmir greeted them.

"Your majesty, this is a great relief!" Horkmir exclaimed. "We saw a bright light in your bedroom, and when we came investigated, you and your bed were gone! May I humbly ask where you have been this whole time? "
"No you may not," Sofia replied. "The events of tonight are to be considered top-secret. On pain of death. Understood?"
"As you wish, your majesty," Horkmir replied.
"Good," Sofia smiled. "Now then, I shall wish to visit our guest. We are not to be disturbed."

Sofia headed up to the room where Largos was staying. She walked in, and saw Largos awake, with 2 guards holding swords up to him, with another stood at the end of the bed.
"What is the meaning of this?" Sofia asked angrily.
"Your majesty!" The guard at the end of the bed exclaimed. "We thought-"
"What?" Sofia asked. "That Largos here had murdered me? Get out, now." The guards quickly left, and Sofia sat down on the chair next to Largos.
"Did they harm you?" Sofia asked him.
"No, just threatened me a little," Largos replied. "They said that if you didn't turn up alive by morning, they'd have me executed for your murder."
"I apologise, it was not my doing," Sofia apologised. "Some things happened tonight, which I feel I should explain to you..."

So Sofia explained everything to Largos, about the arrangements between Janosia and God, and about what had transpired that night.
"So I'm safe now?" Largos asked.
"They will not return for you," Sofia assured him.
"And what about this "God" woman?" Largos asked. "Who is she?"
"She is the almighty being, who rules over the whole universe," Sofia explained. "She is capable of absolutely anything. For 500 years, our planet's monarchy has had a secret agreement with God, where, in return for our planet's worship, she will protect us from danger. It certainly served us well tonight."

"This is all so much to take it," Largos said. "I'd been expecting death, so I don't know what I'll do now."
"You could stay here," Sofia offered. "Build a life from here."
"I think I'd like that Sofia," Largos smiled.
"As would I," Sofia said, standing up. "Good night Largos."
"Good night Sofia," Largos said. "Thank you."

Sofia returned to her room, and found that her bed had been returned to its proper place. On her bedside table, she saw the half-drunk cup of tea and the plate of biscuits she'd been enjoying in heaven. Sofia got back into bed, said her prayers, and then headed to sleep, exhausted.
1343311112212111222111.title: A Visit To The Afterlife

Empress Akina soon returned to her huge palace on the planet Akuman. As she walked the corridors, her staff kept their distance from her more than usual, as they could tell that she was in a bad mood, and if there was something they'd learned, it's that an unhappy Empress was a dangerous Empress. She returned to her room, and pressed a button to materialise some wine. She laid on her bed to sulk.

"So, how did the invasion go?" Asked a female voice in Akina's head. It was slow, and sinister, and it already knew the answer.
"It..um....it was okay," Akina replied, fear obvious in her voice.
"DO NOT LIE TO ME GIRL!" The voice shouted, and Akina yelped. "I SEE ALL!"
"Please, I tried my best!" Akina begged. "But they destroyed our fleet in an instant! We didn't stand a chance!"
"NONE MAY OPPOSE OUR MIGHT! Who is this that dares to destroy our ships?"
"They said they acted on the orders of someone called "God"."

"WHO IS THIS "GOD"!?"
"It seems that whoever "God" is, they defend that planet," Akina replied, trembling in fear. "Perhaps it would be wise to simply avoid the planet in the future?"
"I MUST OWN ALL THE PLANETS IN THE UNIVERSE!" The voice shouted.
"But they promised dire retribution if we returned there," Akina said, before screaming out in agony.
"DO NOT QUESTION ME!" The voice shouted, ending Akina's agony. She then switched to a sweeter voice. "Akina dear, I've been very nice to you. I allowed your family to rule over this empire, and to live in luxury. All I ask in return, is that you conquer worlds for me. I need them after all. You know, there are a lot of people who would wish harm on you. It'd be a shame if say, someone were to let them into the palace."
"Please, I'm sorry..." Akina begged.

134331111222.content:
Sofia returned to her rooms after entertaining Cressida. The angel was clearly new in her role, having neither the obvious long experience of Amia nor the omniscience of Amanda to guide her.

She waved to herself as she entered her bedroom and helped herself undress herself, relieved to be in plain clothes again after having to wear the heavy formal dress that fashion and protocol demanded when entertaining such honoured guests. She wondered if her mother would do something about that; after all, God herself had been wearing clothes much like those she was wearing now, and had been wearing while she was in her bedroom when she was at the dinner.

She felt sorry for Harson. For some reason, he was one of the rare Janosians who was not one of a twinned pair. Usually they were hidden away, embarrassments to their families, but as heir to the throne, Harson was a public figure whether his family liked it or not. Knowledge of the fact that he hadn't split at birth had been suppressed, the attending doctors and midwives bought off with comfortable pensions and very real threats, and when only one body was present at his investiture as Crown Prince six years prior, the Royal Family officially claimed that his other body was in a deep coma. This also conveniently served to explain his aggressive nature, which had been observed in other single-bodied Janosians, and in Janosians with one body heavily impaired. Without two brains operating in parallel, a Janosian was often unable to keep their natural tendencies under control. Old records painted a picture of a time when Janosia had been torn apart by constant war, the wars ending only when every Janosian found themselves in two bodies, but nobody knew just how it happened.

Nobody quite knew just what caused the split at birth, either. Genetic testing on single-bodied Janosians had found any number of differences from the usual Janosian genome, from only a single copy of the fourth chromosome to three of the thirty-first, or sometimes missing genes in the twenty-fifth. Harson, so far as she knew, had three copies of his eighth chromosome, which was new and would have been published in any of Janosia's most prestigious journals had it not been for the need to cover up his difference.

Sofia laughed as she thought about differences. Harson was far from the most unusual member of the family. She sat at her terminal while reading a book and going over her notes from her last lessons with the tutor arriving in a twenty-fifth-day. That would take up a twentieth-day, as usual, and then she would have the rest of the evening to herself. Normally she would have much more time after dinner, but between the necessary formality of that night's meal and having to entertain Cressida, she was not left with a great deal.

It was times like this when she appreciated her own abnormality. Scientists were unable to explain why Janosians split, but they did know that if it weren't for a certain gene, they would keep doing so. There had been a few recorded cases, but the demands on the body were so taxing that Sofia was the first to survive past two years.

Sofia didn't mind. It was useful having more than two bodies, but like Harson's condition, hers was also kept secret. She supposed she had survived as long as she did since she was brought up in luxury. All the previous cases had died of malnutrition shortly after splitting, but after her second split, on her first birthday, the doctor called in recommended that she ingest protein-heavy foods the day before. So unlike her mother and Harson, her birthday was officially celebrated before her actual birthday, and every year it set a new record for feasts.

She had, she knew, over a hundred and thirty thousand bodies, scattered in pairs across the planet. One of the first things she had been taught was how to disguise herself so that the arrangements could be made without anybody knowing all those bodies were her, and she lived not only in the palace but as the daughter of everyone from a poor peasant farmer to the richest corporate tycoon. Already, with her seventeenth birthday a half-year away, arrangements were being made to house her new bodies, and for large amounts of food to be delivered to her current residences at the appropriate time.

She supposed that having so many brains explained her aptitude for mathematics. Certainly it was useful to be able to follow so many different lines of reasoning at once, discarding those that did not work, rather than having to go through them two at a time. She supposed it was also why she was so soft-spoken and calm--she knew that in ordinary Janosians, sometimes their urges got the better of them despite their dispersal, but in her it seemed almost impossible to anger her to the point of provoking a reaction (and how Harson had tried when they were younger).

She was staring off into space while typing at her terminal and flipping through her book and notes when she was almost blinded by a bright light. When it faded, she blinked and turned to look at the intruder from four different angles.

"Your holiness!" she gasped, and scrambled to go on one knee, head bowed.

"Rise, Sofia," said Amanda.

Sofia stood, but did not meet the Goddess's eyes. "How may I serve you, holiness? Shall I call for the Queen? Was there something in the negotiations?"

"No, no. And look me in the eye." Sofia felt her necks being craned upward until she was doing so. "There was nothing wrong in the negotiations. We merely reaffirmed the long-standing arrangement that had existed between God and Janosia since one of my predecessors ended the wars here by creating the twinned pairs."

Sofia's eyes went wide.

"But over the long years things went wrong. The change was merely genetic and prone to mutation and the like. Harson and you are just examples of that."

"Harson--will he bring back the old times? I do worry about that."

"Don't. Part of my end of the arrangement includes keeping Janosia safe from its own rulers, as I do from everything else. Harson will, unfortunately, probably be considered Janosia's worst monarch, and there may be calls for reform to ensure the throne is passed to an able-bodied heir, but no, there will be no return to the warfare that tore this planet apart."

Sofia sighed. "Then what do you want with me? I will never inherit, unless Harson has no children, and I will be old when he dies."

"That is what I want with you--to help you. You are dying, Sofia."

"Dying? How?"

"You know, of course, how draining it is for a mother when she gives birth. Labour is always induced because she needs to eat frantically in the days leading up to delivery, in order to survive the drain her newborn infant will put on her system when it splits. Similarly you must eat a great deal to survive your splits each year, but each time you split, your genes degrade. At this rate, you will not survive long past your eighteenth birthday."

"But you can just fix that, can't you?"

"Even if I were to do that, eventually you would be consuming a significant chunk of the food output of the planet just to survive the splits themselves. The food shipments to your other bodies would be traced, popular opinion would turn against your family and that, not Harson, would cause this planet to be torn apart by war. I must protect your planet from that."

"So then what will you do? If you must put me in just two bodies, I will willingly make that sacrifice."

"No, no," laughed Amanda. "I did not come here to sacrifice you for the well-being of Janosia. I came here to make you an offer."

"An offer?"

"Janosia is hardly the only planet with which I have made the sort of arrangements I have here. But I freely admit that I am new, and I desire as much help as I can reasonably have. You are the ideal candidate to be my focus on those planets."

"Your focus?"

"A lens, if you will, through which I uphold my end of my arrangements. Rather than having to monitor all the planets personally, you would do so for me. You are already used to observing many things at once; I merely offer you the opportunity to do so across the universe."

"And how does this help with my problem? It would merely restart the cycle on all those other planets, as I would require so much food in twenty years' time that all those planets would be faced with the same problem facing Janosia. Besides, you have already said I will die in a few years, so I do not see how I can serve you beyond then."

"Take my hand," said Amanda.

As Sofia did, she felt a warmth flow through her. She watched wide-eyed as wings exploded from her back, her room rearranging itself so that they would not topple anything. She began to hover slightly, and glow.

"Welcome to the ranks of the angels, Sofia."

Suddenly Sofia felt herself scattered across the universe. Only two bodies remained on Janosia, while she felt one body on some planets, two on others, and on a few three or four. She saw Amia and Cressida gasp as she appeared in front of them in heaven.

"This is how you will survive. You are immortal. You will still split on your birthday each year, but the doubles will end up in heaven until I have a new assignment for you. For now, your task is to safeguard the planets to which I have made promises. You will know what to do. But do not reveal who you now are, and do not abuse your power."

Amanda vanished from Sofia's bedroom and reappeared in heaven with Amia, Cressida and Sofia.

"Amia, please show Sofia to her rooms. The endless chambers would be best," said Amanda. "Cressida, Sofia, come with me. Amia, join us as soon as that is done."
134331111222.title: But for the grace of God

1343311112221.content:
The single body of Sofia that had been sent to the planet Vestivia looked on at it, and wasn't pleased with what she saw. The planet was suffering from a huge class divide, where a tiny percentage of the population was living in luxury, while the rest of the people were living in poverty. It hadb't been long since God's influence on the planet had arrived, but unfortunately, very few people accepted God. Vestivia was a very superstitious planet, and unfortunately, those who came proclaiming of a great God in the sky were generally considered to be witches, and were burned or hung as a punishment for conjuring spirits and demons. The original 3 brothers that God had appeared to were dead, and the small group that still worshipped God were forced into hiding. The government was particularly corrupt as well, being more concerned about what they'r'e having for dinner than running their planet.

Vestivia also had legalised slavery. Outside the royal palace was a whole host of slaves bulding a statue of Emperor Shivo, with anyone who refused or physically couldn't either being killed or taken downstairs for "punishment". Sofia had briefly looked at what that involved, and what she had seen had horrified her. Sofia had had enough of this, so she decided to do something about it.

Emperor Shivo was sat in his lounge alone, eating his rather large dinner.
"Hello," Sofia said, appearing next to Shivo, causing him to let out a shriek. "Ooo, that looks nice." Sofia picked up a piece of meat and started eating it, which Shivo looked outraged.
"Who are you!?" He shouted. "Guards! Guards!" Two armoured guards ran in, brandishing thteir swords. "Arrest this girl! Throw her in the dungeon!"
"Uh...what girl your majesty?" One of the guards asked.
"How dare you question me!?" Shivo shouted, even louder. "This girl! Get her out of my sight."
"They can't see or hear me," Sofia said, and then turned to the guards. "You should leave now." Suddenly, the guards turned around and left the lounge.
"Come back here!" Shivo screamed.
"You may as well sit down," Sofia said, sipping a cup of tea that she'd materialised from thin air. "We need to talk."

"You are very insolent for doing this," Shivo said. "I should have you burned for this."
"I'd be more concerned about whether it's you that will be burning," Sofia said. "You see, I represent God. You know, that 'demon' who your guards execute people for worshipping? I was assigned to this planet to monitor it, to see how God's messengers had gotten on. You know, those 3 'witches' you executed a few years ago?
